    The Discovery of Asunaprevir (BMS-650032), An Orally Efficacious NS3 Protease Inhibitor for the Treatment of Hepatitis C Virus Infection

    Abstract

    The discovery of asunaprevir (BMS-650032, 24) is described. This tripeptidic acylsulfonamide inhibitor of the NS3/4A enzyme is currently in phase III clinical trials for the treatment of hepatitis C virus infection. The discovery of 24 was enabled by employing an isolated rabbit heart model to screen for the cardiovascular (CV) liabilities (changes to HR and SNRT) that were responsible for the discontinuation of an earlier lead from this chemical series, BMS-605339 (1), from clinical trials. The structure–activity relationships (SARs) developed with respect to CV effects established that small structural changes to the P2* subsite of the molecule had a significant impact on the CV profile of a given compound. The antiviral activity, preclincial PK profile, and toxicology studies in rat and dog supported clinical development of BMS-650032 (24).

    SPECIAL ISSUE

    This article is part of the HCV Therapies special issue.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We have described the discovery of the hepatitis C virus (HCV) NS3/4A protease inhibitor BMS-605339 (1, Figure 1), which was derived from a tripeptidic acylsulfonamide chemotype.(1) This chemical series introduced the cyclopropyl acylsulfonamide P1′ moiety, a structural element that confers improved potency in the whole cell replicon assays compared to the corresponding carboxylic acid progenitor, an observation that has led to its broad application in NS3/4A inhibitor design.(1, 2) Clinical evaluation of 1 in genotype (GT) 1 HCV-infected subjects revealed that at the highest single dose (120 mg) a mean reduction in viral load of 1.8 log10 IU/mL was observed. However, this trial was ultimately discontinued due to the observation of cardiovascular (CV) events considered to be drug-related. Specifically, mild bradycardia, PR interval prolongation, and junctional escape rhythms occurred in 2 of 12 subjects dosed with 120 mg of 1, one of whom was a normal healthy volunteer (NHV) while the other was infected with HCV. Effects in the electrocardiogram were observed 4 h following dosing and persisted for up to 18.5 h, although both patients remained asymptomatic throughout the observation period. Similar drug-induced CV effects had been observed preclinically in both the dog and rabbit but only in the presence of significantly higher drug concentrations. Thus, humans appeared to be more sensitive to the CV effects of 1, and the potential toxicological ramifications of these findings could not be adequately predicted based on preclinical models.
    Described herein are the results of efforts that culminated in the identification of a second clinical compound from this tripeptidic acylsulfonamide series. Given the favorable antiviral activity associated with 1 in HCV-infected patients and the circumscribed nature of the preclinical and clinical toxicology findings, the objective of the present work was the identification of a compound with preclinical antiviral and pharmacokinetic properties similar to 1 but with a CV profile that held minimal risk for side effects. More specifically, the immediate research objective was the identification of a clinical candidate with high potency toward GT 1a and 1b subtype replicons (EC50 <10 nM), a pharmacokinetic profile predictive of BID or QD dosing, and no evidence of significant CV liabilities in preclinical models.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The maximum total plasma exposure of 1 in the patients experiencing CV effects was 113 nM in the NHV and 206 nM in the HCV-infected subject, with both occurring 1 h postdosing. In conscious, telemeterized dogs administered a dose of 15 mg/kg BID of 1, CV effects were limited to decreases in blood pressure and increases in PR interval, electrophysiological findings generally similar to those observed in humans. These effects in the dogs were limited in magnitude and considered to be manageable. The maximal total drug concentration in plasma was estimated to be ∼12 μM based on parallel studies in nontelemetrized animals. Plasma protein binding of 1 in dog and human plasma, measured by equilibrium dialysis, was found to be 98.2% and 99.1%, respectively, values that are similar and hence do not rationalize the significantly different in vivo concentrations in dog versus human that resulted in the observation of CV effects.(3) The increased sensitivity of humans to the CV effects of 1 compared to dogs meant that using this species to identify compounds free of these CV findings in humans would be challenging and was, therefore, not pursued. The rabbit was explored as an alternative model with heart rate (HR), sinus node recovery time (SNRT), and blood pressure (BP) monitored following intravenous administration (IV) of 1 to anesthetized animals at doses of 1, 3, and 10 mg/kg. Each dose was administered incrementally over a 5 min period, and effects were correlated with total plasma concentration of drug (Figure 2). A mild HR decrease of 32 bpm from baseline was observed 60 min after the last infusion. This HR observation was most significant, as it occurred in the presence of a mild decrease in blood pressure (BP) (−14 to −23 mmHg from baseline), which normally drives a compensatory, reflex HR increase. The observed BP effects were not considered to be drug-related because a similar effect occurred in control animals infused with vehicle. SNRT was slightly prolonged but not significantly different from control and 1 did not affect PR or QT intervals, QRS duration, or AH and HV intervals in the His bundle electrocardiogram. The maximum total drug in plasma in this experiment was 27 μM, while 60 min after the last drug infusion the total plasma concentration was 1.65 μM and the mean drug concentration in cardiac tissue was 0.25 μM. These results indicated that rabbits were also markedly less sensitive than humans to the CV effects of 1 and that this in vivo rabbit model was not a viable toxicology screen for the identification of a second clinical candidate.
    Testing of 1 for in vitro activity at a broad panel of CV receptors, including adrenergic and muscarinic receptors, revealed no significant biological activities that might underlie the observed cardiocasular findings. Ion channels that are predictive of in vivo effects on heart rate, PR interval, or junctional escape rhythms were also explored as a potential source of the CV effects, but 1 produced only weak inhibitory activity in these evaluations. Specifically, at a protein-free concentration of 30 μM, 1 inhibited L- and T-type calcium channels by 36% and 27%, respectively. Inhibition of HCN4, an ion channel thought to play a role in SA node heart rate regulation, was also weak, with 34% inhibition observed. Similar results were found in a sodium channel assay where 1, at a concentration of 30 μM, was associated with only 11% inhibition, a result confirmed in a Purkinje fiber assay where a Vmax reduction of only 8.4% was observed at a drug concentration of 30 μM. In addition, 1 produced only a weak inhibitory effect (<17%) toward the human ether-à-go-go-related gene (hERG) in a patch clamp assay at 30 μM, suggesting low potential for QT-related ECG findings.
    To assess the effects of 1 on cardiac function further and to gather additional insight into the potential mechanism of these observations, studies were conducted in isolated rabbit hearts (Figure 3). The Langendorff isolated heart model enables testing for direct effects on SA node function through measurement of sinus node recovery time (SNRT).(4) Hearts were perfused with protein-free, Krebs–Henseleit solutions containing 1 for approximately 12 min each at concentrations of 0.3, 1, 3, and 10 μM. A mild, concentration-dependent decrease in HR was observed of −15 and −23 bpm from baseline at 3 and 10 μM, respectively, that reflected moderate, concentration-dependent increases in SNRT of ≥+425 ms. Following perfusion with 10 μM of 1, the effects on HR and SNRT continued to increase during a 10 min washout period (−46 bpm in HR and +1250 ms in SNRT). At that time, there were still no significant effects on atrioventricular (A–V) conduction time, QRS duration, or coronary blood flow.
    Isolated rabbit hearts were also perfused with 1 at single concentrations for 60 min to assess the time dependency of the CV effects (Figure 4). At 1 μM, time-dependent effects on HR and SNRT were observed, with a decrease in HR and an increase in SNRT. At a concentration of 0.3 μM, the effects of 1 on HR and SNRT were reduced significantly compared to those at 1 μM, while reducing the concentration further to 0.1 μM resulted in no significant effects when compared to vehicle.(5)
    Collectively, the results of these experiments suggested that the effect of 1 may be a consequence of a direct action on the SA node, which is located in the right atrium of the heart and functions as the primary cardiac pacemaker. Moreover, the similarity of the drug-induced CV effects observed in the Langendorff rabbit heart model with those observed in rabbits, dogs, and humans in vivo was suggestive of a common mechanism operating across species albeit with different sensitivities. The protein-free environment associated with the Langendorff rabbit heart model allowed evaluation of BMS-605339 (1) at free drug concentrations difficult to achieve in vivo in the rabbit or dog, overcoming the differential sensitivity issue, and this model was adopted as a tool with which to evaluate analogues of 1 in an effort to identify those free of CV liabilities.
    The initial series of compounds evaluated in the isolated rabbit heart model (Table 1) were selected in an effort to develop structure–activity relationships (SARs) with respect to the CV findings observed with 1. Truncating the terminal cyclopropyl acylsulfonamide group of 1 to the corresponding carboxylic acid 2 resulted in a compound with significant effects on heart rate and SNRT in the rabbit model, although these effects were less severe than those observed with 1. Nonetheless, this observation exonerated the acylsulfonamide functionality as causative of the CV effects in 1. Given the established value of the acylsulfonamide moiety as a means to drive potency and favorably modulate pharmacokinetic properties, this group was retained as a structural element.(1) Interestingly, analogues of 1 with structural modifications at the P3 and P4 subsites (compounds 3 and 4) also produced effects in the Langendorff model. Furthermore, a reduction in sinus rhythm (HR) and a concomitant increase in SNRT was observed across disparate functionality at P2* (Table 1). Representative analogues bearing a pyrimidine (5) and a carbamate (6) at P2* induced a CV signal and, hence, a structurally distinct P2* ring system that fundamentally circumvented CV effects was unlikely to be identified in an expedient fashion. These findings, coupled with our understanding of the opportunities within the isoquinoline series to optimize potency and PK properties, provided direction, and immediate attention was given to expanding the SARs surrounding the isoquinoline nucleus of this tripeptidic acylsulfonamide chemotype.(1)
    Table 1. Analogues of 1: HCV Inhibitory Potency and CV Profilea
    Table a

    Compounds were dosed at 10 μM for 20 min. When vehicle only was perfused for 20 min, % change in HR and SNRT were −3 and 4, respectively.

    The unsubstituted isoquinoline 7 described previously served as a structural template for optimization, a process that ultimately provided 1.(1) Upon testing in the isolated heart model, 7 elicited effects similar to the 6-methoxy isoquinoline 1 (Table 2). Importantly, the corresponding 5-methoxy isoquinoline 8 demonstrated a significantly improved HR and SNRT profile. A comparison of the results between regioisomers 1 and 8 in the isolated heart model was most significant because it established that marked improvements in the CV profile of compounds were possible via simple structural changes to the isoquinoline ring system. However, while the CV profile of 8 was promising, the activity of this isoquinoline analogue (EC50 = 25 nM) in the replicon assay did not meet the criteria (EC50 < 10 nM) established for further consideration and additional modifications to this ring system were explored. The addition of a second alkoxy substituent to the 5-alkoxy isoquinoline, as in 9, resulted in a decline in activity both in the biochemical assay as well as the whole cell replicon screen.(6) This loss in intrinsic activity in the biochemical assay was attributed to a local conformational preference between the C5 and C6-methoxy groups (Figure 5a), which in the binding pocket of NS3/4A directs the alkyl terminus of the C5-methoxy away from the binding site while projecting the lone pair of the oxygen toward the EF loop carbonyls in a nonpreferential position. In an effort to retrieve the potency lost by the addition of a second substituent, an annulation strategy was considered which restrained the C5 and C6 substituents (10, Figure 5b) in the bound mode observed for parent analogues 1 and 8, as shown in parts c and d of Figure 5, respectively. In this event, the simple dioxolane analogue 10 proved to be more potent than the acyclic 9 in both the biochemical assay as well as the whole-cell replicon screen. However, the metabolic and toxicological liabilities associated with the methylene acetal ring system present in 10 prompted the synthesis of the corresponding dihydrofuran and dihydropyran analogues.(7) Compound 11, which incorporates a C5-dihydrofuran motif, provided excellent activity in the biochemical screen but with modest results in the whole-cell replicon assay. Upon testing in the CV model, 11 proved to be free of the CV liabilities associated with 1. Consistent with this observation the one carbon homologue of 11, dihydropyran analogue 12, which similarly bears a C5-ethereal oxygen, was also free of a CV signal in the isolated heart model. However, the regiosomeric analogues 13 and 14, in which the ethereal oxygen is located at position 6 of the isoquinoline ring system, each elicited a significant signal in the isolated heart model. This SAR was compelling and seemed to implicate the C6 ethereal oxygen present in 1, 13, and 14, as responsible for the CV signal observed with these analogues. Consistent with these findings, the addition of a C6 ethereal oxygen to 12 provided dioxane 16 which, upon testing in the Langendorff model, induced bradycardia and an increase in SNRT. However, not all C5-alkoxy analogues proved to be free of CV liabilities as deannulation of the dihydrofuran ring found in 11 provided the C5-methoxy, C6-methyl analogue, 15, which in the isolated heart model elicited significant bradycardia (−59%) and a substantial increase in SNRT (7296%). Thus, consistent SAR in the CV model was limited to clusters of compounds which were structurally similar with respect to the steric and electronic effects of the isoquinoline substituents. As this balance was easily disturbed, the utility of these findings to predict the profile of related compounds was limited.
    Table 2. P2* Analogues of 1: HCV Inhibitory Potency, PK, and CV Profilesa
    Table a

    Compounds were dosed at 10 μM for 20 min. When vehicle only was perfused for 20 min, % change in HR and SNRT were –3 and 4, respectively.

    Table b

    Compounds were dosed at 10 μM for 60 min. When vehicle only was perfused for 50 min, % change in HR and SNRT were –5 and 16, respectively.

    Table c

    Compound 20 incorporates a valine in place of the tert-butyl glycine.

    From this seam of SARs in the isoquinoline series, 11 demonstrated a promising profile with acceptable antiviral activity and a favorable result in the Langendorff model. Upon IV dosing to rat, 11 demonstrated low clearance (1.4 mL/min/kg) and a half-life of 4 h. The plasma AUC of 11 after oral dosing at 15 mg/kg was 40 μM·h and 24 h plasma and liver concentrations were 0.11 and 0.80 μM, respectively. Hence, 11 was evaluated further with a specific emphasis on the CV profile of this analogue. Upon testing in the isolated heart model for a period of 60 min, 11 exerted only vehicle-like effects on HR and SNRT. In addition, in vivo evaluation of 11 in anesthetized rabbits provided a similar finding: minimal effects on HR and SNRT were observed and no substantial effects on PR, QRS, and QTc intervals, at plasma concentrations ≤177 μM. This plasma concentration of 11 is 6-fold higher than the concentration at which 1 induced bradycardia in this model. Thus, the CV profile demonstrated by 11 was noteworthy as it provided in vivo evidence that the CV effects observed with 1 could be eliminated by modifying the isoquinoline ring substituents. Moreover, a correlation was established between results obtained in the ex vivo isolated heart model with those in vivo. In dogs, 11 demonstrated acceptable oral bioavailability (66%) but high levels of the furan 17 were observed in plasma. In subsequent studies, 17 proved to be a potent inhibitor of CYP 3A4 (IC50 = 69 nM), and further testing of this compound was discontinued.(8) Nonetheless, 17 was critical in establishing the isoquinoline ring system as a vehicle for the identification of compounds free of the CV effects observed with 1 in the rabbit.
    Structure–activity relationship studies in the isoquinoline series continued with the assessment and development of C4-alkoxy-substituted analogues. Initial interest in this series was based on the potency and in vivo distribution profile of the parent compound, 18. This regioisomer of 1 exhibted an EC50 of 19 nM in the GT-1b replicon screen. Moreover, after intraduodenal (ID) dosing to rats, a liver-to-plasma ratio of ∼3700 was observed at the 4 h time point.(1) In the treatment of HCV, a hepatotropic distribution was considered a favorable property because viral replication is believed to occur predominantly in the liver.(10) Moreover, in the clinical evaluation of 1, a significant decline in viral load (0.6 log10 IU/mL) was observed after a 10 mg dose wherein the mean Cmax was 5 nM, which was less than the EC50 observed for this compound in GT-1 replicons. This observation provided indirect evidence suggesting that the liver levels of 1 played a role in mediating the antiviral response of this compound in infected patients. Consequently, the identification of a compound with a hepatotropic distribution was considered a favorable attribute and the profile of 18 was attractive from this perspective.(11) Full PK studies on 18 in rats further illustrated the hepatoselective distribution profile of this compound with liver levels at 24 h relatively high at 4.2 μM and an oral bioavailability of 19%. Upon perfusion of 18 in the isolated heart model at a concentration of 10 μM for 20 min, only mild effects were observed. Further perfusion for a 60 min period at 1 μM resulted in only vehicle-like effects, while escalating to 10 μM resulted in a more significant reduction in heart rate and a concomitant increase in SNRT. The mild CV effects observed for this compound prohibited its development, yet, given the observations made in the C5-alkoxy series wherein CV effects were optimized by further modifications to the isoquinoline ring system, an analogous strategy was adopted in the optimization of 18.
    As illustrated in Table 2, potency was maintained by the addition of a second substituent to the isoquinoline ring system in 18. However, the high liver exposure observed after dosing 18 to rats was not recapitulated with compounds incorporating an additional methoxy substituent. For example, both 19 (4,5-dimethoxy) and 20 (4,6-dimethoxy) showed poor exposure in both plasma and liver after oral dosing. Importantly, the addition of a C3-fluoro substituent to 20 provided 21, a compound which displayed an in vivo distribution profile similar to that of the parent, 18. For example, liver levels of 21 in rats 24 h postdose (15 mg/kg) were 3.4 μM. It should be noted that the CV profile of this set of bis-alkoxy isoquinolines did not meet criteria because significant effects on heart rate and SNRT were observed. However, the PK trend from this series suggested that the synthesis and evaluation of additional analogues of 18 which contained a halogen in the A- or B-ring system was warranted (Table 2). In the event, the C5, C6, and C7 chlorinated analogues of 18 proved to be potent inhibitors of the NS3/4A protease that extended to excellent inhibitory activity in the replicon. These compounds were subsequently evaluated in the Langendorff model, and while 22 and 23 each showed a mild to moderate CV signal, the C-7 chloro isomer 24 was free of CV effects in this model. Given the favorable CV and potency profile for 24 (EC50 = 6 nM), the pharmacokinetic properties of the compound were assessed in the rat. After oral dosing to the rat, 24 demonstrated modest oral bioavailability and a plasma AUC of 1.0 μM·h. However, the 24 h liver levels of 24 after PO dosing were high at 15.2 μM, suggesting a hepatotropic distribution in vivo. Thus, 24 was an important lead, demonstrating on-target potency with a clean CV profile and a favorable hepatotropic distribution.
    A number of close structural analogues of 24 were synthesized in an effort to further optimize the molecule and to systematically evaluate SARs for CV effects. To this end, modifications were made to the C4 and C7 positions of the isoquinoline ring system and to subsites along the peptidic backbone of the molecule (Table 3). Most interesting was the observation that the C7-chloro isoquinoline analogue 25 demonstrated mild CV effects in the Langendorff model. As previously mentioned, the C4-methoxy derivative 18 also elicited a CV signal in this model. Thus, a C7-chloro group and a C4-methoxy moiety as individual entities gave rise to a measurable CV signal, yet, in combination, these substituents function to abrogate completely cardiac effects at the concentrations evaluated.
    Table 3. Analogues of 24: HCV Inhibitory Potency, PK, and CV Profilesa
    Table a

    Compounds were dosed at 10 μM for 20 min. When vehicle only was perfused for 20 min, % change in HR and SNRT were −3 and 4, respectively.

    Table b

    Compounds were dosed at 10 μM for 60 min. When vehicle only was perfused for 50 minutes, % change in HR and SNRT were −5 and 16, respectively.

    Further evaluation of the critical C7 position of the isoquinoline ring established that a chloro moiety was preferred at this site because replacement with fluorine (26) resulted in mild effects in the Langendorff model. In contrast, SARs at the C4 position of 24 suggested that the parent methoxy substituent could be further functionalized. For example, a MEM group, as found in 27, proved to be a suitable replacement for the C4-methoxy in 24. Compound 27 demonstrated a similar CV profile in the 20 min isolated heart model as observed for 24; however, 27 was not advanced in the screening tier due to the relatively weak antiviral activity observed in the replicon assay. A dimethylamine moiety, as in 28, also served as a useful replacement for the C4-methoxy group in 24 because this compound demonstrated a clean CV profile in the 20 min perfusion assay. However, perfusion of isolated hearts with 28 for 1 h resulted in mild effects on HR and SNRT that were significant compared to those with 24 under these conditions. Additional changes to the C4-position of 24 included incorporating a difluoromethoxy substituent, as exemplified by 29, which resulted in a mild CV signal. This SAR point, albeit limited, suggested that in the context of the C7 chloro series, an electron donating C4 substituent was preferable.
    Modifications to the P1 and P4 subsites of 24 were also evaluated. Interestingly, relatively small structural changes to P1, such as saturation of the terminal olefin (30), resulted in very mild CV effects in isolated hearts. Supplementing this P1 change with a trifluorinated P4 Boc cap (31) gave a similar CV profile to 30 in the Langendorff model. The emergence of a CV signal from changes to the P1 subsite suggests that the peptidic core plays some role in affecting cardiac sinus rhythm. Consistent with this hypothesis, perfusion of isolated rabbit hearts with the ketone (32) elicited mild effects (17% HR reduction, 26% increase in SNRT after 20 min at 10 μM). Thus, it appears that CV effects that are pronounced with 1 and abrogated with 24 result from a complex interplay between backbone and P2* moieties.
    Hence, 24 emerged from an extensive SAR study in the isoquinoline series as an optimized compound in terms of potency, PK and initial CV profile and this compound was profiled more extensively. Perfusion of isolated rabbit hearts with 24 at a concentration of 10 μM for 60 min induced only vehicle-like effects on HR and SNRT. The tissue concentration of 24 in the atrium at the end of the experiment was 61 μM, demonstrating significant localization of compound in the region of the heart containing the SA node. The significant difference in outcome for 24 compared to 1 (Figure 6) underscores the impact of small structural changes on CV profile. In rabbits, 24 induced only vehicle-like effects on HR and SNRT as well as PR, QRS, and QTc intervals at high plasma concentrations ≤240 μM (nearly 9-fold that where 1 caused significant effects), providing further confidence to advance this compound. Compound 24 was also tested in the battery of ion channel and cardiac receptor assays described previously; no significant inhibition was noted in these assays at a protein-free concentration of ≤30 μM.
    The clear distinction in CV profiles of 1 and 24 prompted an exploration of the relative solution conformation of these compounds, and this was accomplished by comparing various NMR parameters (chemical shifts, coupling constants, NOEs) acquired in aqueous buffer. The chemical shift of amide hydrogens are sensitive indicators of conformation. Little difference is observed for the chemical shifts of the amide hydrogens in either the tert-butyl glycine substructure (6.54 vs 6.62 ppm in 24 and 1, respectively) or the P1 amino acid moiety (8.31 vs 8.28 ppm in 24 and 1, respectively). In addition, the chemical shifts of other protons throughout 24 and 1 exhibit considerable similarity, the only exception being the shifts arising from the P2* moiety, which is a direct reflection of the altered substitution pattern. Each compound exhibits a preference for an extended conformer as indicated by the NOE pattern along the peptide backbone as well as the observation of large JHN,Hα coupling constant in the tert-butyl glycine substructure (9.66 vs 9.31 Hz in 24 and 1, respectively). All spectroscopic evidence points toward the backbones of 24 and 1 being conformationally similar. However, inspection of NOE cross peaks originating from aromatic protons in the P2* moiety suggests differences may exist in the side chain conformations of the two compounds; considerably more NOEs were observed in 24 than in 1 (Figures 7a,b). NOE contacts are also observed between hydrogen atoms within the cyclopropyl ring of the P1 subsite and the Hβ hydrogens in the hydroxy proline of 24, but analogous interactions were not found in 1. These observations suggest an enhanced conformational mobility of the P2* in 1 compared to 24. While the conformational differences between 1 and 24 are suggestive of a potential source of off-target effects, a direct correlation to CV properties can only be established after NMR analysis of a representative set of compounds and such efforts are ongoing.
    As noted, oral dosing (15 mg/kg) of 24 to rats resulted in plasma exposure of approximately 1 μM·h (F = 12%), with high clearance (38 mL/min/kg) and a moderate half-life of 4.2 h. The clearance of 24 in the rat was substantially higher than the 7 mL/min/kg reported for 1.(1) Consistent with this observation, the 24 liver levels measured for 24 after PO dosing were substantially greater than those observed for 1. The liver levels of 24 measured at 4 h postdosing were 15.2 μM, while at that same time point the levels of 1 in the liver were 0.734 μM. Subsequent in vitro studies in hepatocytes indicated that 24 was taken up into cells by an active transport process, an observation that had also been made with 1.(1) Interestingly, while the hepatotropic distribution of both 1 and 24 appeared to be mediated, at least in part, by transporters, their half-lives in rat liver were significantly different. The t1/2 of 24 in rat liver was 13 h, while that for 1 was much shorter at 4 h. This differential in half-lives between these compounds in the liver may be a reflection of differences in their elimination rates. The PK performance of 24 in dogs was quite similar to that observed for 1, with an oral bioavailability of >50%, and moderate clearance. Upon dosing to monkeys, the oral bioavailability of 24 was low, with moderate clearance observed which compared favorably to the profile observed for 1.(1) An hepatotropic distribution of 24 was observed in both the dogs and monkeys as the liver-to-plasma AUC ratios for these compounds after PO dosing were 40 and 151, respectively. These AUC ratios were less than that observed in rat (359) for 24; however, the result provided evidence of an hepatotropic distribution of 24 across species and provided confidence of a similar outcome in humans.(3) Hence, 24 demonstrated a similar PK profile to 1 across species but with a greater liver disposition observed in rat.
    In the cell-based replicon assay, 24 exhibited an EC50 of 4.0 nM toward the GT-1a strain and 1.2 nM toward the GT-1b strain. The in vitro cytotoxicity profile of 24 in a hepatotoma-derived cell line was also favorable (CC50 = 34 μM), providing a significant therapeutic index. The potency of 24 was approximately 2-fold higher than 1 in the GT 1a and 1b replicon assays. Not surprisingly, the X-ray cocrystal structures revealed the binding mode of these compounds with the NS3/4A enzyme to be quite similar, with only subtle changes in the EF-loop region and the D168-Arg155 interactions seen in response to the P2* group used (Figure 8). In the case of 1, the isoquinoline C6 methoxy group projects into the solvent, whereas the C4 methoxy in 24 projects toward the EF loop. The subtle relocation of the EF loop suggests limited plasticity that is sufficient to accommodate the isoquinoline C4 methoxy substituent in 24. This induces a shift in ring B of the isoquinoline group with the Cl substitution in the C7 position projecting toward Asp168. The impact, based on the co-crystal structure, is a rearrangement of the hydrogen-bond network between Asp168 and Arg155, shifting from a true bidentate salt bridge interaction in 1 to a shared interaction with Arg123 in 24.
    Further profiling of 24 in vitro demonstrated that the compound was a P-glycoprotein (P-gp) substrate and a mild inhibitor of CYP 3A4 (not time-dependent). There was no evidence implicating 24 as an inducer of CYP 3A4 expression. Compound 24 was neither mutagenic (Ames assay) nor clastogenic (in vitro micronucleus assay in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells). Selected in vitro profiling screens for inhibition of enzyme activities revealed no off-target activity for 24 at 10 μM. In conscious telemetered dogs, no significant CV effects were observed after oral administration of 24 which provided Cmax values ≤94 μM. In contrast, 1 produced significant CV effects at a plasma exposure of 12 μM. Additionally, GLP toxicity studies in rats and dogs with 24 supported clinical development of this compound based on Cmax and AUC margins for a projected human dose.
    The antiviral activity of 24 (BMS-650032, asunaprevir) coupled with its pharmacokinetic properties and favorable toxicological profile qualified the compound for evaluation in pre-IND toxicology studies as a prelude to advancing into clinical trials.(3, 13-16) The antiviral activity of 24 was established in a single ascending dose (SAD) study conducted in genotype 1-infected patients followed by a multiple ascending dose (MAD) study in which the drug was administered twice daily for 3 days.(15) At doses of 200–1200 mg of 24, plasma viral RNA declined rapidly with mean maximal reductions of 2.7 and 3.5 log10 IU/mL in the SAD and MAD studies, respectively. Clinical trials designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of 24 in combination with pegylated interferon-α (pegIFN) and ribavirin (RBV), as well as in combination with one or two direct-acting antiviral agents (DAAs) targeting different mechanisms of action in the HCV replication pathway, have been described.(17-22) In the 2-DAA proof-of-concept trial, 24 was combined with the NS5A inhibitor daclatasvir(23) with and without pegIFN/RBV and administered for 24 weeks to HCV GT-1 patients who had previously failed treatment with pegIFN/RBV.(19) In the sentinel cohorts of this trial, of the 11 patients (9 GT-1a and 2 GT-1b) receiving the 2-DAA-only combination, four (2 GT-1a and 2 GT-1b patients) achieved a sustained virological response (SVR) while all 10 patients (10 GT-1a and 1 GT-1b) in the cohort receiving the 2-DAA regimen combined with pegIFN/RBV achieved SVR. This study established for the first time that a chronic HCV infection could be cured by therapy with small molecule DAAs in the absence of the immunomodulatory effects of pegIFN.(18, 21) These results have been confirmed in clinical trials in Japanese patients chronically infected with GT-1b who had previously failed to respond to pegIFN/RBV.(19, 22)
    The synthesis of 24 involved the coupling of three key intermediates 33, 34, and 35 (Scheme 1), and this general approach was employed in the preparation of tripeptide acylsulfonamide analogues described herein. The synthesis of 34 warrants description (Scheme 2), while 35 has been previously described(24) and 33 is a commercially available material. Treatment of cinnamic acid 36 with diphenylphosphoryl azide (DPPA) generated the acylazide 37 as an isolable compound. Thermolysis of 37 in refluxing diphenylmethane catalyzed a Curtius rearrangement followed by ring closure which secured the isoquinoline ring system found in 38 in 53% yield. Selective C4 oxygenation of the isoquinoline nucleus proceeded via a chemoselective ipso substitution that was followed by a halogen-metal exchange reaction and oxygenation. To this end, isoquinolone 38, upon treatment with N-bromosuccinimide in CH3CN, was selectively brominated to provide 4-bromo-7-chloro-isoquinolone 39. Isoquinolone 39 was converted to the C1-chloroisoquinoline 40 by exposure to POCl3 at reflux. Oxygenation of the isoquinoline C4 position in 40 was accomplished in a single operation by a lithium-halogen exchange (n-BuLi, −78 °C), which selectively engaged the C4-bromo group in the presence of both the C1 and C7 chloro substituents. The intermediate aryl-lithium species was quenched by the addition of isopropylboronic acid ester which gave rise to the isoquinoline-4-boronate derivative. In the course of several experiments, this boronate derivative was isolated; however, such workup and characterization proved unnecessary as optimal yields were obtained by subjecting the crude boronate directly to the oxidizing conditions of aqueous H2O2. The process of lithiation, boronate ester formation, and oxidation provided the desired 4-hydroxy-1,7-dicholoroisoquinoline 41 in good overall yield (82%). Importantly, this transformation proved amenable to large scale preparative procedures. The final step in the formation of P2* intermediate 42 was the methylation of the hydroxyl group in 41, which was conducted straightforwardly using either trimethylsilyldiazomethane or MeI in the presence of base. The final step in the synthesis of 34 involved the base-induced coupling of N-Boc-3-(R)-hydroxy-l-proline and 1-chloro-4-methoxy-7-chloro-isoquinoline 42, which proceeded in quantitative yield to provide the desired N-Boc-3-(R)-(4-methoxy-7-chloro-1-oxo-isoquinoline)-l-proline 34.
    The final sequence of reactions (Scheme 3) involved coupling of (1R,2S)-1-amino-N-(cyclopropylsulfonyl)-2-vinylcyclopropanecarboxamide 35 with the functionalized proline derivative 34 to provide the N-Boc-protected dipeptide 43 as a crystalline compound in 88% yield. Intermediate 43 was deprotected to provide the free amine 44 as a crystalline solid, which was coupled with the commercially available N-Boc-t-butyl-l-glycine 33 to provide the final compound 24 in 94% yield. The crystalline hydrate of 24 (Figure 9) was readily generated in methanol with water as the antisolvent.

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The cardiovascular effects observed in the clinic in subjects treated with 1 resulted in the discontinuation of clinical trials with this tripeptidic acylsulfonamide. These CV findings were noted in the presence of low plasma levels of 1, an observation that was surprising given the preclinical CV toxicology profile conducted in both rabbits and dogs where the compound showed only mild CV effects at relatively high plasma levels. The cardiovascular effects of 1 were recapitulated in an isolated rabbit heart model that was utilized to profile and triage lead NS3/4A inhibitors. The CV effects observed for 1 were mitigated by modifications to the P2* isoquinolone ring system, which led to the identification of 24 (BMS-650032, asuanprevir) as a compound free of the cardiovascular liabilities found in the first clinical compound. The antiviral activity, PK, and toxicological profile of 24 met the targeted criteria, and this compound was advanced into clinical trials. Notable were the elevated levels of 24 found in the liver across species after IV or PO dosing in conjunction with its potency against GT 1a and 1b replicons which provided high EC50 multiples 24 h after dosing. The activity of 24 translated into a robust antiviral response in early clinical trials. In an important proof-of-concept clinical trial, 24 was combined with the NS5A replication complex inhibitor daclatasvir as part of an interferon-free, RBV-free regimen. Not only was this the first study to show that patients infected with GT-1 could be cured with a DAA-only regimen, it was also the first study to show that difficult-to-treat prior nonresponders to IFN-based regimens could be cured of infection. Phase 3 studies with 24 and daclatasvir have now been completed, and if approved, this DAA-only regimen has the potential to provide GT-1b HCV-infected patients with therapy of superior safety and efficacy relative to the currently approved regimens.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Methods

    Sample Analysis for in Vitro and in Vivo Studies

    Samples obtained from pharmacokinetic studies were analyzed by LC/MS/MS. Analysis was by multiple reaction monitoring using positive ion mode. Declustering potential and collision energy were optimized for each compound. Plasma samples were prepared by protein precipitation/filtration using organic solvent containing internal standard (IS) as follows. First, 200 μL of the IS solution was added to each well of a protein precipitation filter plate (Strata, Phenomenex, LA). Then biological samples (50 μL) were added to the filter plate, such that a 4:1 v/v solvent/sample ratio was achieved. The filter plate was placed atop a standard 96-well plate, and the entire unit was centrifuged at 1000 rpm for 2 min. The supernatant was collected in the 96-well plate, and an aliquot (10 μL) was first injected onto the TFC extraction column and then back-eluted onto a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) column for LC/MS/MS-based analysis. For the analysis of liver samples, tissues were homogenized in phosphate buffer/CH3CN (80/20, v/v) and the resulting homogenates were prepared for analysis using protein-precipitation followed by online TFC extraction as described for plasma samples. If dilutions were required, an aliquot of the sample was diluted into the respective matrix. Analysis of samples from full PK studies were conducted against standard curves ranging from 2 to 10000 nM. Each standard curve was fitted with a linear regression weighted by reciprocal concentration (1/x2). Standards were analyzed in duplicate. Quality control samples were prepared in blank biological matrix at concentration levels within the range of the standard curve and were analyzed as replicates within each analytical set.
    All animal studies were performed under the approval of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Animal Care and Use Committee and in accordance with the American Association for Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care (AAALAC).

    Rat Pharmacokinetics

    Male Sprague–Dawley rats (300–350 g, Hilltop Lab Animals, Inc., Scottsdale, PA) with single or dual indwelling jugular cannulas were used (N = 3 per group). Rats dosed orally were fasted overnight, while those intravenously dosed were not fasted. Compounds were administered either IV (5 mg/kg, 10-min infusion) or orally (15 mg/kg, gavage) in PEG-400/ethanol (9:1). Serial blood samples were obtained from the jugular vein cannulas of all animals at 0 (predose) and at 0.17 (or 0.25 for oral), 0.5, 0.75, 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 24 h post dose. These samples (∼0.3 mL) were collected into K3EDTA-containing tubes and then centrifuged at 4 °C (1500–2000g) to obtain plasma, which was stored at −20 °C until analysis by LC/MS/MS. Excised tissues were rinsed, blotted dry, weighed, and stored frozen until processed for analysis by LC/MS/MS. Screening studies were conducted as described above with truncated time points (0 (predose), 0.17 (IV only), 0.5, 1, 2, 4, and 6 h with livers were taken at terminal time point).

    Data Analysis

    The pharmacokinetic parameters were obtained by noncompartmental analysis of plasma concentration versus time data (KINETICA software, version 2.4, InnaPhase Corporation, Philadephia, PA). The peak concentration (Cmax) were recorded directly from experimental observations. The area under the curve from time zero to the last sampling time (AUC0-t) was calculated using a combination of linear and log trapezoidal summations. The plasma clearance (CL = dose/AUC after IV dose) and elimination half-life (T1/2) in plasma and livers calculated from following equation: T1/2 = 0.693 × volume/clearance.

    Ion Channel and Purkinje Fiber

    Test agents were evaluated in vitro for effects on potassium (hERG/IKr), L- and T-type calcium, sodium (SCN5A), and pacemaker (HCN4) channels, and rabbit Purkinje fiber action potentials. Ionic current measurements were performed using the whole cell patch clamp technique. Human ion channels (hERG, sodium, L- and T-type calcium, HCN4) stably expressed in human embryonic kidney cells (HEK 293) were used as test systems. In the hERG assay, effects on hERG currents were calculated by measuring inhibition of peak tail currents. In the sodium channel assay, effects were calculated by measuring inhibition of peak inward currents at two stimulation frequencies, 1 and 4 Hz, to assess rate-dependence of interaction. In the T-type and L-type calcium channel assays, and the HCN4 assay, effects were calculated by measuring inhibition of peak inward currents.
    Action potential parameters were measured in isolated rabbit Purkinje fibers using a conventional intracellular technique. Action potential parameters measured included resting membrane potential, overshoot, maximal upstroke velocity (Vmax), and time to 50% and 90% repolarization.

    Isolated Perfused Rabbit Heart

    Hearts were excised from anesthetized rabbits and perfused in a retrograde manner through the aorta at a constant pressure and temperature (37 ± 0.2 °C) with oxygenated Krebs–Henseleit bicarbonate buffer. A bipolar ECG was recorded via electrodes connected to an ECG amplifier. A pair of recording electrodes was placed on the epicardium of the left atrium and pair of stimulating electrodes was placed on the epicardium of the right atrium for atrial stimulation. Flow of the perfusate through the coronary arteries was monitored and recorded via an extracorporeal flow probe. The atrial electrogram, ECG, and coronary flow were continuously monitored and recorded via a Ponehmah physiology platform (Data Sciences International, St. Paul, MN). Data were expressed as mean ± SD and were compared using student t test.
    The primary end point of the studies was SA node function; the secondary end points were cardiac conduction (A–V conduction, QRS duration), QT interval, and coronary flow. SA node function was evaluated by measuring SA node recovery time (SNRT) and sinus rate (HR). SNRT was defined as the longest A1–A2 cycle length after atrial pacing. In some experiments, test agents were perfused at different concentrations in ascending order in each heart. Each concentration was perfused for 10 min without washout between concentrations. All parameters were measured at baseline and after 10 min perfusion at each concentration. Data were averaged from 1 min recording at baseline and after 10 min perfusion at each dose. To study the effects of a single concentration of test agent over a longer time period, rabbit hearts were perfused for 1 h with test agent and data were analyzed every 10 min throughout the perfusion period.
    At the end of the study, the atria were weighed and snap frozen in liquid nitrogen and were stored frozen at −20 °C until all studies were done. To measure tissue concentration, the atria were thawed at room temperature and 1 g of tissue was homogenized in 2 volumes of homogenization buffer (800 mL acetonitrile (HPLC grade no. 9017-03, JT Baker, Phillipsburg, NJ):200 mL Hank’s balanced salt solution (catalogue no. 14175-095, Invitrogen, Carlsbed, CA). Tissues were homogenized on ice at 13500–17500 rpm using short bursts of a T25 basic S1 generator (IKA Works, Wilmington, DE) with an S25N-8G dispersing tool until a uniform suspension is achieved. The suspension was centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 min at 4 °C, and the supernatant was analyzed for BMS-650032 concentrations as previously described.

    Anesthetized Rabbit Electrophysiology

    Experiments were performed in propofol–fentanyl anesthetized closed-chest rabbits (n = 4). The primary end point was SA node function reflected by SA node recovery time (SNRT) and sinus rate (HR). SNRT is defined as the longest A1–A2 cycle length after atrial pacing. A1 represents the last beat of an atrial pacing train, and A2 the first spontaneous sinus beat after pacing. The secondary end points were cardiac conduction (A–V conduction, QRS duration) and QT interval. The atrial and His bundle electrograms were continuously monitored and recorded via intracardiac leads that were connected to Prucka CardioLab 7000. Body surface ECG (lead II and III) and arterial blood pressure (BP) were continuously monitored and recorded at 500 Hz (Ponehmah) at a logging rate of 10 s. Compounds were intravenously infused at 1, 3, and 10 mg/kg via an infusion pump. PEG400:ethanol (9:1) was used as vehicle. Each dosage was achieved by 5 min infusions. SNRT was measured 2 min later. The interval between dosage escalations was 15 min. Blood (plasma) samples were taken 2 min after the end of the first two infusions and 5, 15, 30, and 60 min after the final infusion for determination of compound concentration. Data were averaged from a 1 min recording interval immediately before blood sampling and are expressed as mean ± SEM. Data were compared with vehicle control using student t test.

    Dog Cardiovascular Telemetry

    The potential hemodynamic and electrocardiographic (ECG) effects of acute oral doses of test agents were evaluated in conscious dogs monitored by telemetry. Four instrumented beagle dogs (two of each sex) were given 1 at 30 mg/kg given as 15 mg/kg BID separated by 4 h dosed in gelatin capsules as a solution in 20% α-tocopheryl polyethylene glycol 1000 succinate (TPGS) in 4 mM sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), pH 10.0. Six instrumented beagle dogs (three of each sex) were administered 1 at 100 mg/kg given in gelatin capsules as a solution in polyethylene glycol 400 (PEG-400) and TPGS (60:40 v/v). Each dog served as its own control and received the test article vehicle 1 day prior to and 5 days after test agent administration. Systemic blood pressure (systolic, diastolic, and mean), left ventricular end-diastolic pressure, lead II electrocardiogram, core body temperature, and activity were monitored via radiotelemetry implants (Integrated Telemetry Systems) for approximately 20 h after each vehicle or test article administration. The first derivative of left ventricular pressure signal, +dP/dt, was calculated as an index of left ventricular contractility. Additional parameters evaluated included clinical signs (through approximately 6 h after the initial BID dose via remote video monitoring, and during periods of animal handling) and toxicokinetics (4 and 6 h after the initial dose). Six instrumented beagle dogs (three of each sex) were administered 24 at 100 mg/kg given in gelatin capsules as a solution in PEG-400 and TPGS (60:40 v/v) and similarly evaluated by telemetry.

    CYP Inhibition Assay

    To assess the potential for a drug candidate to inhibit CYP450 enzymes, microsomes expressing individual human recombinant CYP450s and fluorogenic CYP probes that produce fluorescent metabolites were used. The CYP450 enzymes includes CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, CYP2D6, CYP3A4-BFC, and CYP3A4-BzR and were conducted in duplicate in 384-well plates using a high-throughput assay format with robotic liquid handling. Briefly, test compounds are dissolved in DMSO (20 mM) with positive controls added along with compounds following the same dilution process as the compounds. Using a TECAN Genesis, the 100% DMSO/compound solutions are serially diluted, 1:3, to 10 concentrations. The 100% DMSO/compound solutions were then diluted with water to 0.6% DMSO. The final DMSO concentration in the assay is 0.2%. The top test concentration for the test compounds is 40 μM. After prewarming of the assay plates in an incubator (37 °C) for 10 min, a mixture of substrate and cofactors in the appropriate potassium phosphate assay buffer was added. The enzyme/substrate pairs are 1A2, 3-cyano-7-ethoxycoumarin (CEC), 2C9, 7-methoxy-4-trifluoromethylcoumarin (MFC), 2C19, 3-cyano-7-ethoxycoumarin (CEC), 2D6, 3-[2-(N,N-diethyl-N-methylamino)ethyl]-7-methoxy-4-methylcoumarin (AMMC), 3A4, 7-benzyloxy-4-trifluoromethylcoumarin (BFC), and 3A4, benzyloxyresorufin (BzR) . The final cofactor concentrations are 1.3 mM NADP+, 3.3 mM glucose-6-phosphate, and 0.4 U/mL glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase for all enzymes except 2D6. The 2D6 assay has final cofactor concentrations of 0.0081 mM NADP+, 0.41 mM glucose-6-phosphate, and 0.4 U/mL glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. The reactions were initiated by the addition of enzyme in the appropriate potassium phosphate assay buffer. The enzyme source for the assays were cDNA-expressed isozymes prepared from baculovirus-infected insect cells supplied from BD Biosciences Corp (Woburn, MA). The assay plates were returned to the incubator (37 °C) until the appropriate times at which plates were removed for analysis. The reaction in each plate was quenched by the addition of 80% acetonitrile/20% 0.5 M TRIS base, except for the 3A4-BzR assay that was read immediately after the 45 min incubation. The amount of fluorescent product formed in each well was determined by analysis using a LJL Analyst plate reader. The data from the reader was exported and analyzed using Xlfit curve-fitting software to calculate the 50% inhibitory concentrations (IC50).(26)

    NMR

    Compound Synthesis

    All reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without purification unless otherwise noted. All anhydrous reactions were performed under a N2 atmosphere using SureSeal solvents from Aldrich. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker AM FT 300 MHz spectrometer, a Bruker AvanceIII 500 MHz spectrometer, or a Bruker Ultrashield 400 MHz spectrometer, each equipped with a 5 mm TXI cryoprobe. All spectra were determined in the solvents indicated, and residual protio-solvent was used as internal standard for chemical shift assignments. Interproton coupling constants are reported in hertz (Hz). Multiplicity patterns are designated as follows: s, singlet; d, doublet; t, triplet; q, quartet; m, multiplet; br, broad; dd, doublet of doublets; dt, doublet of triplets; dq, doublet of quartets and most spectra were analyzed using the ACDLABS SpecManager 12.0 program software. Note: at ambient temperature in DMSO-d6, most of the final products exist predominantly as a mixture of rotamers.
    All compounds were determined to be at a purity level of greater than 95% as detemined by liquid chromatography methodologies. Liquid chromatography/mass spectra (LCMS) were performed on a Shimadzu LC instrument coupled to a Water Micromass ZQ instrument and the LCMS conditions are shown in Table 4.

    Preparation of 7-Chloroisoquinolin-1-ol (38)

    DPPA (27.5 g, 0.1 mol) was added dropwise to a solution of (36 (18.3 g, 0.1 mol) and Et3N (20.2 g, 0.2 mol) in benzene (100 mL). After stirring for 2 h, the solution was concentrated and the residue purified by silica gel chromatography (20% EtOAc/hexanes) to give 16 g of 37 as a solid. Intermediate 37 was dissolved in Ph2CH2 (100 mL) and the mixture slowly heated to 90 °C over a 30 min time period. The solution was heated to reflux and maintained at this temperature for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, a solid precipitated which was collected by filtration and washed with toluene to provide 38 (9.5 g, 53%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.24 (d, J = 2.27 Hz, 1 H), 7.67 (d, J = 2.01 Hz, 1 H), 7.66 (s, 1 H), 7.18 (d, J = 7.05 Hz, 1 H), 6.66 (d, J = 7.05 Hz, 1 H). LCMS (method D): tR = 1.86 min. LCMS (ESI) m/z calcd for C9H6ClNO, 179.01; found, 179.92 (M + H)+.

    Preparation of 4-Bromo-7-chloroisoquinolin-1-ol (39)

    A slurry of 38 (36.33 g, 203 mmol) and N-bromosuccinimide, (39.74 g, 223.3 mmol) in anhydrous CH3CN (500 mL) was slowly heated to a gentle reflux over a period of approximately 2 h and maintained at a gentle reflux for 1.5 h. After cooling to room temperature over a period of 3 h, the precipitated solid was collected by filtration and washed with CH3CN (100 mL × 3) to provide 39 (47 g, 90%) as a solid. This material was used in the next step without further purification. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.27 (d, J = 2.00 Hz, 1 H), 7.88 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1 H), 7.81 (dd, J = 8.40, 2.00 Hz, 1 H), 7.46(s, 1H). LCMS (method D): tR = 2.21 min. LCMS (ESI) m/z calcd for C9H5BrClNO, 256.92; found, 257.80 (M + H)+.

    Preparation of 4-Bromo-1,7-dichloroisoquinoline (40)

    A heterogeneous solution of 39 (47 g, 182 mmol) in POCl3 (200 mL, 2.15 mol) was slowly heated to reflux over a period of 1 h and then was maintained at reflux for 4 h before being cooled to room temperature and concentrated in vacuo to remove excess POCl3. The residue was dissolved in of CH2Cl2 (600 mL), cooled to −35 °C, neutralized, and subsequently basified carefully with 1 N NaOH (400 mL) until the mixture was pH = 8. The organic layer was separated, washed with H2O, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residual solid was crystallized from EtOAc (approximately 50 mL) to give 32 g of 40. The mother liquor from the crystallization process was concentrated and purified by silica gel chromatography (16% EtOAc in hexanes) to provide an additional 4 g of 40 as a solid. In total, 36 g (73%) of 40 was obtained. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.48 (s, 1 H), 8.34 (d, J = 1.76 Hz, 1 H), 8.14 (d, J = 9.06 Hz, 1 H), 7.80 (dd, J = 8.81, 2.01 Hz, 1 H). LCMS (method D): tR = 2.55 min. LCMS (ESI) m/z calcd for C9H4BrCl2N, 274.89; found, 275.76 (M + H)+.

    Preparation of 1,7-Dichloroisoquinolin-4-ol (41)

    To a slurry of 40 (22.16 g, 80 mmol) in THF (500 mL) maintained at −78 °C was added 1.6 M n-BuLi in hexanes (100 mL, 160 mmol) dropwise via cannula over 15 min (the internal temperature was maintained ←65 °C). The solution was stirred for 0.5 h, and (i-PrO)3B (37 mL, 160 mmol) added dropwise via syringe over 10 min (the internal temperature was maintained ←65 °C). The reaction mixture was stirred for 0.5 h, and 30% H2O2 (80 mL, 776 mmol) was added dropwise via an addition funnel over 10 min (the internal temperature rose to −60 °C during this addition), followed by addition of 1 N NaOH solution (80 mL, 80 mmol). The cooling bath was removed, and the reaction mixture allowed to warm to room temperature and stirred for an additional 1 h. After confirming the completion of the reaction by LC/MS, the reaction mixture was cooled to −40 °C, and a solution of of Na2SO3 (100 g, 0.793 mol) in of H2O (400 mL) was added dropwise over 30 min (the internal temperature was maintained between 5 and 10 °C). The resulting slurry was neutralized with 6N HCl (∼50 mL) at 0 °C to provide a pH ∼ 6 solution. The mixture was diluted with of EtOAc (500 mL) and transferred to a 2 L separatory funnel. To the remaining solid in the reaction vessel was added H2O (500 mL) and EtOAc (300 mL) and the mixture neutralized with 6N HCl (∼20 mL). The organic layers were combined and washed with brine (300 mL × 3) and H2O (200 mL × 3). The organic phase was dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated to give a crude product which was triturated with EtOAc (50 mL). The solid was collected by filtration, rinsed with EtOAc (3 × 25 mL), and dried to provide 11.8 g of 41. The filtrate was concentrated and the residue purified by silica gel chromatography (35% EtOAc in hexanes) to give an additional 2.1 g of 41. In total, 27.9 g (82%) of 41 was obtained. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.23 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1 H), 8.16 (d, J = 2 Hz, 1 H), 7.76 (dd, J = 8.8, 2, Hz, 1 H), 7.4 (s, 1 H). LCMS (method D): tR = 2.32 min. LCMS (ESI) m/z calcd for C9H5Cl2NO, 212.97; found, 213.88 (M + H)+.

    Preparation of 1,7-Dichloro-4-methoxyisoquinoline (42)

    To a slurry of 41 (16 g, 75.5 mmol) in MeOH/CH3CN (30 mL/300 mL) maintained at 0 °C was added dropwise a 2 M solution of TMSCHN2 in hexanes (60 mL, 120 mmol). The reaction mixture was warmed to room temperature and stirred for 14 h. The solution was concentrated, and the residual solid was recrystallized from EtOAc (about 50 mL) to give 8.1 g of 42, which was washed with 25% EtOAc in hexanes. The mother liquor was concentrated and the residue purified by silica gel chromatography (16% EtOAc in hexanes) to provide an additional 3.2 g of 42 as a solid. In total, 11.3 g (66%) of 42 was obtained. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 4.05 (s, 3 H), 7.67 (dd, J = 9.06, 2.01 Hz, 1 H), 7.80 (s, 1 H), 8.16 (d, J = 8.81 Hz, 1 H), 8.23 (d, J = 2.01 Hz, 1 H).

    Alternate Preparation of 1,7-Dichloro-4-methoxyisoquinoline (42)

    To a stirred solution of 41 (7.2 g, 33.6 mmol) in DMF (100 mL) maintained at 4 °C was added CH3I (4 mL, 64.2 mmol) followed by NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 2.52 g, 63.0 mmol). The bright-yellow solution was stirred at 4 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was neutralized by the addition of 70 mL of 0.5N HCl, and 50 mL of brine was added to the mixture. An off-white solid precipitated that was collected by filtration and washed with 200 mL of H2O followed by 100 mL of pentane to provide 7.4 g (97%) of 42. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.24 (d, J = 1.96 Hz, 1 H), 8.16 (d, J = 9.05 Hz, 1 H), 7.80 (s, 1 H), 7.67 (dd, J = 8.80, 1.96 Hz, 1 H), 4.05 (s, 3 H).     X-ray Co-crystal Structure of HCV NS3/4A Protease Complexed with 24

    Methods for protein expression and purification have been reported.(27) A solution of the NS3/4A protease enzyme (20 mg/mL) in 25 mM MES buffer at pH 6.5, 500 mM NaCl, 2 mM DTT, and 5% v/v glycerol was incubated with 4.3 mM 24 (5-fold molar excess) for 2 h at room temperature. The complexed protein was centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 10 min and then 0.2 μm centrifuge filtered. Crystals were grown by the hanging drop vapor diffusion method. A 12–24% v/v PEG 1500 gradient evenly divided across 24 reservoir solutions, which also was buffered by 100 mM HEPES at pH 7.5, was used to screen for crystallization conditions. For this complex, the optimal PEG 1500 concentration was 18% v/v. Plate-like crystals were harvested after 7 days. A 20% v/v glycerol solution prepared with the reservoir solution was used as the cryoprotectant. The crystals belonged to space group P21 with unit cell parameters of a = 45.4 Å, b = 67.8 Å, c = 61.3 Å, and β = 108.5°. A data set was collected at the Bristol-Myers Squibb research facility in Princeton, NJ. A Rigaku FR-E generator and Osmic MaxFlux HR multilayer optics were used to generate the well-collimated X-ray beam. A Rigaku R-axis IV++ image plate detector was used to record the diffraction images which were processed with the HKL suite.(28) Diffraction data were recorded from 50.0–2.2 Å resolution. Overall, the data set was 99.4% complete with an average I/σ(I) of 12.3, Rmerge of 9.3%, and redundancy of 3.5. The highest resolution shell, 2.28–2.20 Å, was 98.0% complete with an average I/σ(I) of 4.8, Rmerge of 26.3%, and redundancy of 3.3. The structure was determined by molecular substitution based on another structure of this same crystal form. The structure was refined by three cycles of model building with QUANTA(29) and refinement with CNX.(30) The current crystallographic residues, R and Rfree, are 23.9% and 28.9%, respectively.
    Accession Codes

    The PDB code for 1 is 4NWK and for 24 is 4NWL.

      2g
      Induced-Fit Binding of the Macrocyclic Noncovalent Inhibitor TMC435 to its HCV NS3/NS4A Protease Target
      Cummings, Maxwell D.; Lindberg, Jimmy; Lin, Tse-I.; de Kock, Herman; Lenz, Oliver; Lilja, Elisabet; Fellander, Sara; Baraznenok, Vera; Nystrom, Susanne; Nilsson, Magnus; Vrang, Lotta; Edlund, Michael; Rosenquist, Asa; Samuelsson, Bertil; Raboisson, Pierre; Simmen, Kenneth
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (9), 1652-1655, S1652/1-S1652/11CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      We have detd. the crystal structure of the macrocyclic inhibitor TMC435 bound to its HCV NS3/4A protease target at a resoln. of 2.4 Å, providing at. detail of induced fit to an extended S2 subsite. The complex structure helps to rationalize the impact of key modifications in the optimization path that led to 1, and is guiding our understanding of resistance patterns. Future modeling and structure-based design efforts aimed at NS3/NS4A protease should benefit from the new structure, which represents the first example of a noncovalent NS3/NS4A protease-inhibitor complex deposited in the PDB and details the induced fit involved in accommodating a large P2 substituent. Inhibitors with large P2 groups that occupy the extended S2 subsite probe the crystallog. obsd. helicase-protease interface, and it is hoped that future studies will clarify the relevance of interfacial contacts to protease activity and protease inhibitor binding.

      2k
      Improved P2 phenylglycine-based hepatitis C virus NS3 protease inhibitors with alkenylic prime-side substituents
      Lampa, Anna; Ehrenberg, Angelica E.; Gustafsson, Sofia S.; Vema, Aparna; Aakerblom, Eva; Lindeberg, Gunnar; Karlen, Anders; Danielson, U. Helena; Sandstroem, Anja
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 18 (14), 5413-5424CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Phenylglycine has proven to be a useful P2 residue in HCV NS3 protease inhibitors. A novel π-π-interaction between the phenylglycine and the catalytic H57 residue of the protease was postulated, and it was hypothesized that the introduction of a vinyl on the phenylglycine might strengthen this π-π-interaction. Thus, a series of acyclic vinylated phenylglycine-based HCV NS3 protease inhibitors, e.g., I, was synthesized and their inhibitory potency evaluated. Surprisingly, inhibitors based on both D- and L-phenylglycine were found to be effective inhibitors, with a slight preference for the D-epimers. Furthermore, prime-side alkenylic extension of the C-terminal acylsulfonamide group gave significantly improved inhibitors with potencies in the nanomolar range (∼35 nM), potencies which were retained on mutant variants of the protease.

      Discovery of novel urea-based hepatitis C protease inhibitors with high potency against protease-inhibitor-resistant mutants
      Kazmierski, Wieslaw M.; Hamatake, Robert; Duan, Maosheng; Wright, Lois L.; Smith, Gary K.; Jarvest, Richard L.; Ji, Jing-Jing; Cooper, Joel P.; Tallant, Matthew D.; Crosby, Renae M.; Creech, Katrina; Wang, Amy; Li, Xianfeng; Zhang, Suoming; Zhang, Yong-Kang; Liu, Yang; Ding, Charles Z.; Zhou, Yasheen; Plattner, Jacob J.; Baker, Stephen J.; Bu, Wei; Liu, Liang

      Discovery of Vaniprevir (MK-7009), a Macrocyclic Hepatitis C Virus NS3/4a Protease Inhibitor
      McCauley, John A.; McIntyre, Charles J.; Rudd, Michael T.; Nguyen, Kevin T.; Romano, Joseph J.; Butcher, John W.; Gilbert, Kevin F.; Bush, Kimberly J.; Holloway, M. Katharine; Swestock, John; Wan, Bang-Lin; Carroll, Steven S.; DiMuzio, Jillian M.; Graham, Donald J.; Ludmerer, Steven W.; Mao, Shi-Shan; Stahlhut, Mark W.; Fandozzi, Christine M.; Trainor, Nicole; Olsen, David B.; Vacca, Joseph P.; Liverton, Nigel J.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 53 (6), 2443-2463CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A new class of HCV NS3/4a protease inhibitors which contain a P2 to P4 macrocyclic constraint was designed using a mol.-modeling derived strategy. Exploration of the P2 heterocyclic region, the P2 to P4 linker, and the P1 side chain of this class of compds. via a modular synthetic strategy allowed for the optimization of enzyme potency, cellular activity, and rat liver exposure following oral dosing. These studies led to the identification of clin. candidate vaniprevir, MK-7009, which is active against both the genotype 1 and genotype 2 NS3/4a protease enzymes and has good plasma exposure and excellent liver exposure in multiple species.

      Novel Macrocyclic Inhibitors of Hepatitis C NS3/4A Protease Featuring a 2-Amino-1,3-thiazole as a P4 Carbamate Replacement
      Di Francesco, M. Emilia; Dessole, Gabriella; Nizi, Emanuela; Pace, Paola; Koch, Uwe; Fiore, Fabrizio; Pesci, Silvia; Di Muzio, Jillian; Monteagudo, Edith; Rowley, Michael; Summa, Vincenzo
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 52 (22), 7014-7028CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      The discovery of P2-P4 macrocyclic inhibitors of HCV NS3/4A protease characterized by high levels of potency and liver exposure was recently reported. Within this novel class of inhibitors, a structurally diverse series of compds. I [X = isoquinoline-1,7-diyl, 2-phenylquinoline-4,6-diyl, 2-carbonyl-1,3-dihydroisoindolyl; Y = (CH2)2, (CH2)3, CH2CMe2; Z = thiazol-2,4-diyl, 1,3,4-oxadiazol-2,5-diyl; R1 = i-Pr, t-Bu, cyclohexyl, (S)-EtCHMe, cyclopentyl; R2 = H2C:CH, Et] featuring a 2-amino-1,3-thiazole as replacement of the carbamate in P4 was identified. Optimization studies focused on structural modifications in the P3, P2, and P1 regions of the macrocycle as well as on the linker chain and resulted in the discovery of several analogs characterized by excellent levels of enzyme and cellular activity. Among these, I [double bond; X = 2-carbonyl-1,3-dihydroisoindolyl; Y = (CH2)3; Z = thiazol-2,4-diyl; R1 = (S)-EtCHMe; R2 = H2C:CH] displayed an attractive pharmacokinetic profile in preclin. species and showed sustained liver levels following oral administration in rats.

      (a) Murray, M. Mechanisms of inhibitory and regulatory effects of methylenedioxyphenyl compounds on cytochrome P450-dependent drug oxidation Curr. Drug Metab. 2000, 1, 67– 84

      7a
      Mechanisms of inhibitory and regulatory effects of methylenedioxyphenyl compounds on cytochrome P450-dependent drug oxidation
      Murray, Michael
      Current Drug Metabolism (2000), 1 (1), 67-84CODEN: CDMUBU ISSN:. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review with 110 refs. Cytochrome P 450 (CYP) enzymes catalyze the oxidative conversion of drugs and other lipophilic compds. to hydrophilic metabolites. Thus, CYPs play a dominant role in the elimination of drugs from the body. Inhibitory interactions occur when drugs compete for oxidn. by specific CYPs, whereas certain drugs increase the capacity for oxidative biotransformation by inducing the synthesis of new CYPs. Methylenedioxyphenyl (MDP) compds. have been widely employed as com. important pesticide synergists and a no. of derivs. are found in oils and spices. MDP compds. are of considerable toxicol. significance because of their capacity to inhibit and induce CYP enzymes in mammals; some derivs. produce neurotoxic and hepatotoxic effects. Although there are relatively few therapeutic agents of present clin. importance that possess the MDP structural feature, the synthesis and preclin. evaluation of such agents appears to be increasing. In the context of the existing literature surrounding MDP compds. it is noteworthy that these potential drugs also elicit significant modulatory effects on CYP activities in rat and human liver. These developments indicate the importance of understanding the chem. mechanisms by which MDPs interact with CYPs. Thus, the presence of the MDP structure may undermine the potential clin. value of new drugs.

      7b
      Reactive Metabolites in the Biotransformation of Molecules Containing a Furan Ring
      Peterson, Lisa A.
      Chemical Research in Toxicology (2013), 26 (1), 6-25CODEN: CRTOEC; ISSN:0893-228X. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Many xenobiotics contg. a furan ring are toxic and/or carcinogenic. The harmful effects of these compds. require furan ring oxidn. This reaction generates an electrophilic intermediate. Depending on the furan ring substituents, the intermediate is either an epoxide or a cis-enedione with more ring substitution favoring epoxide formation. Either intermediate reacts with cellular nucleophiles such as protein or DNA to trigger toxicities. The reactivity of the metabolite dets. which cellular nucleophiles are targeted. The toxicity of a particular furan is also influenced by the presence of competing metabolic pathways or efficient detoxification routes. GSH plays an important role in modulating the harmful effects of this class of compd. by reacting with the reactive metabolite. However, this may not represent a detoxification step in all cases.

      8
      Time-dependent CYP inhibition
      Riley, Robert J.; Grime, Ken; Weaver, Richard
      Expert Opinion on Drug Metabolism & Toxicology (2007), 3 (1), 51-66CODEN: EODMAP; ISSN:1742-5255. (Informa Healthcare)
      A review. Time-dependent inhibition (TDI) of CYP refers to a change in potency during an in vitro incubation or dosing period in vivo. Potential mechanisms include the formation of inhibitory metabolites and mechanism-based inhibition (MBI). In vitro expts. are configured to assess TDI and MBI is inferred, at least initially. MBI is more profound after multiple-dosing and the recovery period is independent of continued drug exposure. Advances in in vitro-in vivo extrapolations for competitive inhibition and the potential relationship between MBI and reactive metabolite-mediated toxicity, have redirected emphasis to CYP TDI. In contrast, with reversible inhibition, strategies for projecting the risks from TDI are less developed and the traditional I/Ki model often yields a dramatic underprediction. This review explores the contribution of TDI to drug-drug interactions and idiosyncratic drug toxicity.

      Asunaprevir: HCV serine protease NS3 inhibitor treatment of hepatitis C virus
      Reviriego, C.
      Drugs of the Future (2012), 37 (4), 247-254CODEN: DRFUD4; ISSN:0377-8282. (Thomson Reuters)
      A review. Hepatitis C virus (HCV) currently affects more than 170 million people worldwide. Over 80% of the infected individuals develop chronic hepatitis, which leads to other complications, such as cirrhosis, fibrosis or liver carcinoma. The current std. of care (SOC), which combines pegylated interferon alfa (pegIFN-α) and ribavirin, has limited efficacy in providing a sustained virol. response, esp. in HCV genotype 1-infected individuals. Moreover, the lengthy treatment with SOC is frequently assocd. with undesirable side effects that may be extremely debilitating. There is therefore an urgent medical need to develop anti-HCV therapies that are safer and more effective. Asunaprevir (BMS-650032) is an investigational, oral, selective serine protease NS3 inhibitor with pharmacokinetic parameters that suggest once- or twice-daily administration. Its promising safety profile, in addn. to the encouraging clin. proof-of-concept results, make asunaprevir attractive for use in drug combination studies with other HCV therapeutic agents, even in interferon-free regimens and for difficult-to-treat patient populations.

      13b
      Resistance analysis of the hepatitis C virus NS3 protease inhibitor asunaprevir
      McPhee, Fiona; Friborg, Jacques; Levine, Steven; Chen, Chaoqun; Falk, Paul; Yu, Fei; Hernandez, Dennis; Lee, Min S.; Chaniewski, Susan; Sheaffer, Amy K.; Pasquinelli, Claudio
      Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy (2012), 56 (7), 3670-3681CODEN: AMACCQ; ISSN:0066-4804. (American Society for Microbiology)
      Asunaprevir (BMS-650032) is a potent hepatitis C virus (HCV) NS3 protease inhibitor demonstrating efficacy in alfa interferon-sparing, direct-acting antiviral dual-combination regimens (together with the NS5A replication complex inhibitor daclatasvir) in patients chronically infected with HCV genotype 1b. Here, we describe a comprehensive in vitro genotypic and phenotypic anal. of asunaprevir-assocd. resistance against genotypes 1a and 1b using HCV replicons and patient samples obtained from clin. studies of short-term asunaprevir monotherapy. During genotype 1a resistance selection using HCV replicons, the primary NS3 protease substitutions identified were R155K, D168G, and I170T, which conferred low- to moderate-level asunaprevir resistance (5- to 21-fold) in transient-transfection susceptibility assays. For genotype 1b, a higher level of asunaprevir-assocd. resistance was obsd. at the same selection pressures, ranging from 170- to 400-fold relative to the wild-type control. The primary NS3 protease substitutions identified occurred predominantly at amino acid residue D168 (D168A/G/H/V/Y) and were assocd. with high-level asunaprevir resistance (16- to 280-fold) and impaired replication capacity. In asunaprevir single-ascending-dose and 3-day multiple-ascending-dose studies in HCV genotype 1a- or 1b-infected patients, the predominant pre-existing NS3 baseline polymorphism was NS3-Q80K. This substitution impacted initial virol. response rates in a single-ascending-dose study, but its effects after multiple doses were more ambiguous. Interestingly, for patient NS3 protease sequences contg. Q80 and those contg. K80, susceptibilities to asunaprevir were comparable when tested in an enzyme assay. No resistance-assocd. variants emerged in these clin. studies that significantly impacted susceptibility to asunaprevir. Importantly, asunaprevir-resistant replicons remained susceptible to an NS5A replication complex inhibitor, consistent with a role for asunaprevir in combination therapies.

      17
      Preliminary study of two antiviral agents for hepatitis C genotype 1
      Lok, Anna S.; Gardiner, David F.; Lawitz, Eric; Martorell, Claudia; Everson, Gregory T.; Ghalib, Reem; Reindollar, Robert; Rustgi, Vinod; McPhee, Fiona; Wind-Rotolo, Megan; Persson, Anna; Zhu, Kurt; Dimitrova, Dessislava I.; Eley, Timothy; Guo, Tong; Grasela, Dennis M.; Pasquinelli, Claudio
      New England Journal of Medicine (2012), 366 (3), 216-224CODEN: NEJMAG; ISSN:0028-4793. (Massachusetts Medical Society)
      BACKGROUND: Patients with chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection who have not had a response to therapy with peginterferon and ribavirin may benefit from the addn. of multiple direct-acting antiviral agents to their treatment regimen. METHODS: This open-label, phase 2a study included an exploratory cohort of 21 patients with chronic HCV genotype 1 infection who had not had a response to previous therapy (i.e., had not had ≥2 log10 decline in HCV RNA after ≥12 wk of treatment with peginterferon and ribavirin). We randomly assigned patients to receive the NS5A replication complex inhibitor daclatasvir (60 mg once daily) and the NS3 protease inhibitor asunaprevir (600 mg twice daily) alone (group A, 11 patients) or in combination with peginterferon alfa-2a and ribavirin (group B, 10 patients) for 24 wk. The primary end point was the percentage of patients with a sustained virol. response 12 wk after the end of the treatment period. RESULTS: A total of 4 patients in group A (36%; 2 of 9 with HCV genotype la and 2 of 2 with genotype lb) had a sustained virol. response at 12 wk after treatment and also at 24 wk after treatment. Six patients (all with HCV genotype la) had viral breakthrough while receiving therapy, and resistance mutations to both antiviral agents were found in all cases; 1 patient had a viral response at the end of treatment but had a relapse after the treatment period. All 10 patients in group B had a sustained virol. response at 12 wk after treatment, and 9 had a sustained virol. response at 24 wk after treatment Diarrhea was the most common adverse event in both groups. Six patients had transient elevations of alanine aminotransferase levels to more than 3 times the upper limit of the normal range. CONCLUSIONS: This preliminary study involving patients with HCV genotype 1 infection who had not had a response to prior therapy showed that a sustained virol. response can be achieved with two direct-acting antiviral agents only. In addn., a high rate of sustained virol. response was achieved when the two direct-acting antiviral agents were combined with peginterferon alfa-2a and ribavirin.
